p.seg: (He) being from Wu, why does it not refer to him as as a Viscount?
That is because he turned back to his barbarian ways.
What did this returning to the barbarian ways consist in?
(The answer is this:) A ruler is to reside in the ruler's place,
and the dignitaries are to reside in the place of the dignitaries.
(In this case) it would appear that he had it off with the mother of the king of Chǔ.
Since Wú was in charge of the meeting why does it first mention the Marquis of Jìn? (NOTE THE SCOPE OF 先]
This is because it is not permitted for a barbarian to be in charge of central states.
Why does it write:say "with the Viscount of Chǔ?"
This is an expression for the organising a meeting of two leaders.
If one was not going along with the ruler of barbarians being in charge of central states
why does one express this the formulation "organising of a meeting between two leaders"?
This is because they stresses the importance of Wú.
Then why did they stress the importance of Wú?
This is because when Wú is present anywhere (in a certain meeting place) then none of the feudal lords would fail to meet up.
